reviewText:
Forza 5 is the racer I really want to play but this game is scratching that itch for me at the moment on PC.

The handling is very sensitive and each car takes some getting used to but is eventually very satisfying to drive. A good range of difficulty settings and driver assists which you can switch off means you can give yourself a fair challenge and feel satisfied when you drive well. The helmet camera and head physics were my favourite feature from the first Shift game and they return in Shift 2 to make the sensation of racing at speed only just in control of your car, really engaging. Unfortunately the immersion for me goes no further as there is no support for the Microsoft Xbox 360 Wireless Racing Wheel which is my wheel of choice on PC, although in fairness plenty of Logitech wheels are supported. This limitation plus the distinctly floaty nature of the cars' handling causes me to play this game as more of an arcade racer than I do a game like Forza 4, but it is still enjoyable when played with the right expectation. The trusty 360 gamepad is supported and works very well for racing as you would expect. The menus are mostly easy to navigate with the 360 pad but all the on-screen button prompts are for the keyboard. It took me a while to work out how to save settings with the controller (press start) but after some trial and error I can deal with the menus well enough.

Shift 2 has a wide selection of real cars and tracks plus a smattering of fictional courses, some of which return from the first game. Full car customisation is provided allowing you to upgrade the performance and customise the appearance of the vehicles quite dramatically. Cars are given an overall performance rating and using this are separated into categories A, B, C, D just as in the original Shift game and familiar to players of other racing sims such as Forza Motosport.

The game looks pretty good in 1080p and on my machine (i5, 7850, 8GB RAM) with all presets set to High runs at 50-70 frames per second on the whole, though on certain corners of certain tracks framerate drops into the high 30s. I would like to tweak my settings a bit more to achieve a minimum of 60 but the game offers no benchmark mode so checking the effect of a graphics setting takes a long time - many changes even require you to restart the game. It is also disappointing that the low resolution cutscenes were clearly pre-rendered with consoles in mind which makes the unskippable cinematics during the career mode look very out-dated - cinematics should be used to flatter a game, but in the case of Shift 2 it's a relief to get past them and into the game which itself looks very attractive.

The Autolog and Online play require an EA Origin account (though the game does not require the Origin client). Unlike some players on the community hub I had no trouble at all activating the game or fighting with any DRM. The game installed and played easily from Steam just like any other game. Steam Overlay popped up showing me the product key when I first launched the game but I dismissed that as I have never had to type it in yet. I have tried to get an online match on two occassions and both times I was the only player online and had to create a lobby. Hopefully the sale weekend will get some new players lobbying up but I would not recommend this title if you are looking for multiplayer racing. It does provide a satisfying single player experience for players who enjoy racing against AI and testing themselves on simulations of the best cars and circuits in motorsport.

To my mind this game was a good buy at the recent sale price of £4.99 but I would hesitate to recommend it at the current full price of £19.99. It is true there are not a lot of other games of this type available on the PC which have the same degree of polish as Shift 2 Unleashed, but there are definitely better experiences out there on Steam for your hard-earned £20.

reviewText:
I played this game using the unofficial community patch by nogripracing, so I have no experience with the Vanilla version. Also I didn't delve deep into the tuning options and online.

As of this writing I clocked in around 37 hours and I am confident to say I really love this game. I played through the first SHIFT and it was my first ever racing game that made the cockpit view comfortable to play with. SHIFT 2 refined the experience with their new Helmet Cam -- The camera is attached to the driver's helmet and it mimics the head movement and shakiness when driving, gives you tunnel vision, and it blurs your vision when you hit a wall. A lot of people say the camera is disorienting, but personally I don't really think so. I was not once disorientated, confused or the effects got in the way of the gameplay. SHIFT 2 is arguably the only racing game that lets you truly be the driver, rather than be the car itself. You feel how scary speed is when driving at 200 miles per hour, underestimate the car, and the car will severely punish you. This what made this game so great for me.

Now for the negatives. The menu system is stylish, but atrocious. The key assignments for the buttons are all over the place. I am playing using the 360 controller and the game can't reassign the button icons to match the controller's.

Earning money is way too easy. Want to buy that certain car? Grind in Quick Race once your driver level is high. Select the Dakota Oval track, set it to one lap and no opponents, and bam, $20,000 per 35 seconds.

Visual customization is basic and practically useless.

The slightest bump and the slightest touch to the dirt will send your car spinning. To be fair, I haven't rammed a car or drove off-road in real life before, but these annoyances can ruin the entire race because the AI suddenly bumped into you or you get sucked to the dirt like a black hole.

Some of the DLCs are way too easy and one DLC broke the game's pace. The Speedhunter pack gives you the drag racing career, quarter mile career and access to some highly tuned cars. The problem is the cars are free to acquire. I won the drag race and quarter mile career without breaking a sweat because I had free access to the stupidly fast Nissan GT-R. Some of these cars can be used to your default career and I breezed past some of the events.

My narrator-guy-person-thing is annoying. I loved the British guy in SHIFT 1 and while the new guy is alright, he's too, uh... Not... I dunno. He's not British-ey and kawaii enough.

I hate drifting. I hate drifting in SHIFT 1, and I hate drifting in SHIFT 2.

The title of the game is stupid. Really? SHIFT 2 Unleashed? What's next? SHIFT 3 Insurrection? SHIFT 4 Reloaded?

Overall I love this game. The negatives are there and noticeable, but the core gameplay, the cars, the races, the tracks, the sights and sounds, are all great.

I've played NFS: HS (Road Challenge), PU (P 2000), HP 2, MW '05, MW '10 and this - a true NFS fan, that is.

Pros:
- Physics, realistic loss of traction at high speeds (aye, I've also driven a real car at high speed and lost traction, so I would know).
- Lots of interesting game modes.
- Lots of interesting tracks, specifically I like how this game doesn't do cheap stuff like track mirroring or obnoxious night time ice skating to bump up difficulty. I also like how some tracks have several variants with common bits.
- No catch-up! You actually get what you deserve as far as I can tell. Difficulty is dynamically adjusted in the beginning of each race according to your performance but never mid-race as it used to be.
- Graphics are stunning, camera options are good and make a lot of sense (e.g. two different in-cockpit cams with different settings).
- Background graphics because no flux were given :D
- Lots of settings for the car*
- No DLC ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, existing cars are all good enough to beat the events, your friends and even clock some serious records.

Cons:
- Loads of CTDs and sound bugs. For me the source of CTD persists over the CTD, e.g. if I was playing track A with settings XYZ and it crashes, it's gonna crash with track A and XYZ no matter how many times I restart the game. I've read through the reviews - laughing. So many reviews about the game crashing 24/7 or whatsoever. I can't even recall that it has crashed. I've played both Shift and Shift 2 on my Xbox360 before I got this on pc. Both were great. Looking back at previous Need for Speed games, these two were big improvements. Doesn't feel like Need for Speed, but it's still awesome.

I am quite pleased, BUT two things I can think of now that really bothers me are the Al behavior and those childish cutscenes.
The Al are challenging, but in a bad way. I play on hard difficulty because I like a challenge. However, the Al opponents keep hitting and crashing into me, even each other. Looks like they're really trying hard to push you of the track instead of finishing the race. These cutscenes just makes me feel bad. They talk about racing and how it is in real life. It's a long speech which you cannot skip.

Despite those childish cutscenes and deathwish Al opponents, the game is amazing.
- Runs smooth 24/7 with optimal graphics (Not crashing at all).
- Lots of tracks
- A much bigger selection of cars than earlier games. You can have as many as you want and in addition several of the exact same car. Even cars from previous decades can be driven.
- Drifting is completely different from NFS Carbon where it doesn't feel realistic at all.
- Just driving at all is exciting. Often I just drive without opponents in cars I love.
- It is nice to see they use many of the same cars they've used before.

I am happy that they actually made Need for Speed that can be called somewhat realistic. Playing Hot Pursuit made me feel bad, watching the trailer for the newest Need for Speed doesn't make me feel any better. I am very pleased with this game. This is a game for everyone who either loves racing or simply enjoys driving.

reviewText:
This game is my favorite racing game and I always use it to get my through my Forza-thirst whenever a new Forza game comes out (I don't have an Xbox).

I think this racing game is really really great. However, I can't recommend it to anyone because of a long list of bugs and problems to look out for.

First, this game ships with broken Physx so your tutorial race probably will crash the game immediately. There's a workaround for this, but this shouldn't happen in the first place.

Next, even though the multiplayer is dead, sometimes a track will crash on loading as it contacts EA's servers. The workaround is to play with your internet disabled, but that shouldn't happen either.

And finally, if you do everything you should, this game will crash anyways. Quite a bit. Fortunately, it's typically before the race starts, but sometimes it will in the middle of the race anyways.

In the end, I think this is a really good racing game, but is so buggy for something from a major publisher and major franchise that I can't recommend it.

However, if you can overlook these flaws, this is a really fun and cheaply-priced Forza-like racing game. When it plays, it's fantastic. But it WILL crash on you and you WILL need to do silly workarounds to get it to stop crashing most of the time.

reviewText:
You can have lots of fun playing Shift 2 if you have an adaquate computer and a good steering wheel.  Even then you will probably have to turn most of the stability aids on, in order to not be driving on ice.  With my computer you need something better than a G27 for this game to be drivable.  A Thrustmaster T500 will do, but it will probably break after a few months.   Be prepared to do quite a bit of tweeking to get this game to remotely resemble real driving.  There is a patch to fix some of this that has been released by gamers, but it cannot be applied to the Steam version.  So maybe the bargain bin at Frys or equivalant would be the best place to buy this game.

The good thing about this games is it is fun, you can drift through turns at 150mph and not wreck.  In fact you will have to learn to do this because the cars are continuously loosing grip.
It looks pretty good too for it's age.  You can easily customize you cars apperance and performance.

This game has no multiplayer ability.
The worst thing about this game is the AI.  It is horrendous.  I frequently have wished that I had the programmer tied up in my basement so that I could slowly beat them to death with a chain.

Really, it is that bad.  This was programmed by the same people who still don't seem to be able to do a competent AI in Project Cars.  So be prepared for opponents that you beat the entire race, have a huge lead on, and then magically appear at the last turn driving faster than is possible to beat you  (rubber-banding).

Also be prepared to be smashed into becasue the AI is not actually intelligent.  These other cars will do little if anything to avoid crashing into you, and will at times actively seek to crash into you.  It doesn't matter at all if you drive like a gentleman youself.  You may not think this is a big deal, but if you spend a half hour in an endurance race, and have a chance of winning then some nimrod bumps you off the track, and in Shift2 you are the one who gets the penalty and you lose.  This will happen over and over, and you too will wish the programmers were tied up in your basement.

reviewText:
I played Shift 1 and instantly fell in love with the game - I couldn't wait to get shift two... especially when the price dropped :)!

I would say out of all racing games there are and even compared to Grid : Autosport, I have to give the cake to Need For Speed Shift 2 on this one. Just an absolutely beautiful racing game. Very enjoyable to drive, drift, turn, race, crash, and cutting off other drivers to take the lead.

The visuals are stunning. Seriously, what else do you want from an automotive game? This is 2014, we're all expecting decent graphics by now.

The game play more importantly is what makes this game stand out from other racers. Sure this isn't the classic NFS where you run from police, but this NFS is more simulation based and can make your heart skip when taking a turn. There are suggestive arrows on the track to tell you how fast to take a turn, however they are suggestions may I remind my reader. They change accordingly to your speed but I feel once you get the hang of how a car handles you don't quite need to rely on them heavily. The tracks are a perfect length and I haven't run into any races that I've dreaded (meaning those races that you have to race for 10-15 minutes at a time). Tracks are also nice, challenging, fun, and some turns just really get you into the game. I've never been a gamer to turn my controller for racing (or any games for that matter) and this was the first game where I felt that displacing my controller may do something (it doesn't but that's how immersed I can get playing). The small drift and loss of wheel control when taking major turns is impeccable. If you do over do a turn and end up hitting the wall, your screen goes hazy and gray to simulate impact. This I do not find annoying but rather amusing and realistic. Damage to your car is also pretty spot on.

This game get's a solid 8.3/10. Why the extra .3 over my solid rating of 8? The game modes, the UI, just how it was all put together just makes it so nice.

reviewText:
Well its a jekyl and hyde affair really with what could of been the best racing game ever, but ruined a bit by a couple of flaws.

What it gets right is the track realism, the variety of cars, the custom options, the career mode and there is plenty of challenge in there for all. You can customise your cars setup, tune it, and the realism of the cockpits and sounds seem to represent the real life cars. V6s, V8s V12s and turbos all sound different.

Unfortunately the things it gets wrong is the cars handling is a bit unresponsive with gamepads as there is some sort of controller input lag on this setup, but ive heard this isnt the case if using wheels.

The other annoying thing is the Computer cars AI is excessively aggressive at times, where they will deliberately swerve off their racing line to shunt you off the road when you attempting to overtake. The collision physics is all wrong and biased here too in favour of the computer cars, whereby a tiny contact will send your car shooting off like a rocket whilst the computer car barely gets affected.

Shame really, because is could of all been amazing but its let down by some flaws.

Overall would give a 7/10, but it could of been a 9 or 10 if the other issues were fixed.

I have poured hours of this game into the origin version, and had it rebought on steam because of an apparent patch that was released only to this version without EA's notice - basically improves graphics at the cost of a massive green screen :P So whatever.

This game in comparison to other racing games, particularly Forza and Gran Turismo on the consoles, is rather low on car variety and has less tracks as well.
So what does this game have that they don't?

This game provides that ♥♥♥♥ing masterpiece that is Need for Speed racing enviroments, soundtrack, and being able to do exactly what they want to do in each game - shooting for realism this time around, it came out in a FANTASTIC way, allowing you to adjust every setting to go from basically being an arcade racer to being a full on simulation with full support for external wheel/shifter/pedal controllers of every sort (Logitech G27 in my case). The graphical style is outstanding, and I say that because without the use of extreme filters and such like Need for Speed Rivals for example, it still pulls of a rather impressive appearance if a bit dated (It did come out in 2011, after all).

Your car lineup covers a number of cars across almost every popular brand out there save ferrari and a few others, but I will admit the variety of cars from each manufacturer is rather low in comparison to its main competitors on the console market out there. However, each car feels unbelievably well detailed and simulated, and while it is possible to get this game on console as well you are going to want it on PC due to the fact that this game feels like it was DESIGNED for PC, not console.

The enviroment is really what gets you though. Other racing games are effectivelly nothing short of boring menus until you start a race. This one gets that soundtrack, enviroment, gets the sounds down perfectly on each car and area, the camera angles right, helps you to feel motivated to get out there and kick ♥♥♥.

This is a game I highly recommend to racing fans out there. Even today, it stands up very well. Just be careful of the premature patch issued to this steam version if you don't know what you're doing - you actually might want to get it on disc or origin in this case, believe it or not.

reviewText:
I must admit to being rather disappointed by this game when i first bought it, so left it gathering dust for quite a while afterwards. However, after enjoying the original NFS: Shift for the umpteenth time i decided to give this another try... and i'm glad i did.

In many ways this is more of the same, only with a new, rather cluttered layout and inferior graphics (sadly). There are more cars (a LOT more) to choose from, more circuits, more events... and i'm pleased to say the engine sounds are every bit as good as they were in the original. But one of the changes didn't agree with me. I really don't like the default helmet cam view, and i can see it being off-putting to a number of people, so changing it back to the same cockpit view as used in the first NFS: Shift game was essential. The other major change is one that initially i didn't like, but now i'm finding it great...

Upgrading your car is no longer as simple as it was in Shift. Now as your car is upgraded, it's performance rating increases, and as it increases it is possible that it is no longer eligible for the class that you are still racing in. I'll use my current car as an example. The Audi R8 is a Class C car with a performance rating of 920. If that rating reaches 1000 or more, it becomes a Class B car, and can no longer be used in Class C events. This means you have to be careful when choosing your upgrades, do you go for top speed, acceleration, or handling... or only a slight improvement in all 3? This means you have to think about your upgrades carefully. Thankfully you can sell all upgrades (and purchased cars) back for the same price you bought them, so if the upgrades you've chosen aren't working out for you, get rid of them and try experimenting with different ones. This means it's no longer as simple as just slapping on every single upgrade for your car as soon as you can afford them... chances are you can afford far more upgrades than you can actually fit while remaining in your racing category. This also has the benefit of being able to keep your favourite Class C car, but giving it the performance to genuinely compete in Class B, maybe even Class A, races.

The pure racing arcade game is no longer quite as mindless as the first Shift game... and i personally think that makes this a great game that is well worth buying.

reviewText:
This is a tough game to properlly review, so please take the thumbs up with a grain of salt at the moment. On its own, the game has a host of unique features and problems as compared to its competitors (especially of those on the consoles.) Then compared to the original Shift game, it also made some improvements but cut where it shouldn't have.

But let's start with the basics. This is a simulator racing game. Or at least, that is what it is classified as. If you are wanting an open world experience with pursuits, save yourself the heartache and look at just about any other Need for Speed title because this game has none of that. This is a game that tries to create professional races with opponents that are about evenly matched with you as possible.

So how does it do to that? Well, again, it comes in with a mixed bag. No, I can't honestly say that this is the most accurate game possible, but it isn't going to let you off with bad driving. In true Need for Speed fashion, the car list feels rather small and this time around we have a lot of repeating cars. Customization is a bit hit or miss as while we finally have engine swapping with the more specific engine parts to upgrade (not to the point of realism though,) there is still a linear upgrade in body kits and the vinyl designing seems to be even worse. At the very least, all cars can be upgraded with Works. Thankfully, tuning can be either simplified or extremely technical while also allow saving different settings for a given car for each track. Yep, you can have a special setting for the short, technical track and a different one for those at higher speeds and the game will automatically switch out based off the track and layout.

The gameplay is where the game begins to shine over others though. Traffic is actually a thing as smashing your way through opponents is a bad idea over trying to (almost) safely weave through them. Night racing is absolutely wonderful and I have yet to find another racing game that tops it as while well lit tracks don't bring much issue, unlit tracks like the Nürburgring become a lot more difficult (and almost scary) to drive with not always being able to see around the corner. AI can also be fairly aggressive but not to the point of cheating or actually being unsportsman. If you play with the camera on dask or on helmet, the race feels more intense as it bobbles around like you are in the car itself, making even a quick run around a track by yourself in a low end car feel more intense than others with AI drivers with high end vehicles.

The helmet cam is also a new feature to this game (that will probably leave due to things like the occulus rift.) The camera will look into the turn like a professional driver. While it takes some getting use to at first, it is well executed and does end up becoming quite helpful especially in larger vehicles but probably not needed for triple monitors.

All of that said, Shift 2 is a fairly good place for people to try and break into the simulator genre. The game has a level system based on what you do and mini-achievments per race, meaning that just because you have a hard time winning doesn't mean you can't progress to the end. While different from the previous Shift title, it still does the job well at letting new players still get a chance to eventually move on but without being a hinderance to veterans of the genre.

Now, how about against the original Shift? Well, more improvements and new issues. Yes, night time racing is a wonderful feature, helmet camera is appreciated, and the improved graphics are wonderful. But they have removed the unnamed crew chief who started the race for you with a real world professional driver. And yes, you will know that the new person helping you is a professional driver. And yes, it becomes a nusiance. No, Shift 2's new guy doesn't have an annoying voice but that it feels like he is lecturing you for every single race instead of seeming like you are part of the same team. We go from a grassroot driver becoming a legend to a grassroot driver who is forever in the shadow of his teacher. And then they brought in the rest of the real world drivers. Yep, every boss race is you against a real world racer betting their car against you. No weakness and they are not that interesting especially when almost all of them are driving a car sponsored by EA. I get that they might be trying to create buzz for the drivers, but this isn't a good way to get me excited for them.

Allow me to wrap this up. Wanting a typical Need for Speed game? I recommend Hot Pursuit by Criterion. Want a super realistic simulator? Might be worth your time. Just want a fun yet fairly challenging racing game? This is probably up your alley. Looking for the proper sequel to Shift? Prepare for disappointments and be pleasantly surprised at certain points.

reviewText:
Shift 2: Unleashed is as good as Need for Speed: Shift was bad. Bold statement as Shift 1 was widely praised for splitting the franchise and moving into the racing sim genre, breaking away from Need for Speed’s arcade roots. But it wasn’t quite there. Shift 1 was a prototype for the formula, testing what worked and what didn’t. What definitely didn’t work were the physics and handling. Floaty, unresponsive and still clinging to the series traits. An EA inclusion more than Slightly Mad Studios, as the UK developers were definitely capable of more precise and realistic handling based on their earlier GTR games.

However, the cockpit view was an absolute blessing and Shift 2: Unleashed drastically improves the handling to match the visually stunning cockpit view.

Gameplay

Shift 2’s cockpit view is the best and most visceral experience I’ve ever seen in a racing game. Not only is it highly accurate and detailed, the cockpit also features amazing effects. Wing mirrors shake at high speeds, vision is blurred at those speeds, the dashboard is reflected on the windscreen, shifting, handbrake and pedal actions are all intricately animated, dirt flicks on to the windscreen, rubber and gravel ‘marbles’ hit the undercarriage and wheel arches and high speed crashes cause violent shaking, temporary loss of vision and heavy breathing from the driver. Also the option to have a helmet camera further emphasises the impact as well as the precision as the head sways towards the corner direction for added realism. The third person camera offers the chance to view the detailed cars from behind but it doesn’t offer the connection the player has with the car as the camera is a bit too floaty, I like that word, making it hard to aim for the apexes.

Luckily, the improvements in handling have made it much easier to point a car at an apex. Turning off all assists, except ABS and Automatic (c’mon now), produces the most rewarding driving experience in a racing game. Throttle control is vital as well as judging the braking zone and corner angle all to get the best exit creating intense racing. Immersion can be broken however by the slightly over-aggressive AI drivers who have no problem PIT manoeuvring you off the track or blocking you on straights. A little more Jenson and little less Pastor would’ve made a less frustrating battle for 1st. This is tied to the fact that Unleashed doesn’t have a rewind feature made popular by Codemasters and now prominent in the Forza series. Thank God though, as racing intensifies in the latter stages making it a white knuckle ride to the finish line without a safety net.

Career progression is improved above and beyond Shift 1’s silly star system as well as the XP rewards being based on good driving rather than awarding careless racing. Videos by real-life racers and drifters such as Vaughn Gittin Jr. introduce each racing category and you are provided the opportunity to learn and hone the skills before heading out on track. Need for Speed fans are also given extra cash and cars for their dedication to the franchise, which helps save up cash to buy their dream cars. Unlike Shift 1, to race a car in Hot Lap mode, you have to buy the car in career mode. Perhaps unfair, but it gives a real incentive to finish gold in every race and manage the cash in order to afford the cars you really want. Helpfully, cars can be sold for the price bought making it easy to sell the lower-powered sports cars necessary for a category in order to save for a hypercar.

The car list is smaller than GT5 or Forza 4, but it ignores the unnecessary hatchbacks and endless Nissans of the GT series. The cars here are focussed racing machines and monstrous production cars all with beautifully detailed interiors and exteriors with moving airbrakes and wings. Not included are any Ferraris but the Porsche selection more than makes up for it. The diverse variety of tracks features all the greats such as Suzaka, Silverstone and Spa as well as an interpretation of the Monaco GP circuit.

Technical

The sounds are loud. My headphone volume was at 50% most of the time and sometimes lower at night. The cars sound great though and the noticeable differences in sound from the cockpit view to behind the exhaust demonstrate the attention to detail that Slightly Mad paid. The graphics are impressive not just the cars but also the track surroundings, including helicopters and planes flying over whilst racing. Night racing is also a welcome addition with tactics having to alter and slight apprehensiveness when approaching blind bends. The ability to turn off HUD whilst in-game is also a brilliant addition as you can have the lap times and positions when you need them and turn them off to not obscure the view without breaking the flow of the race.  The framerate could be improved though as modding was the only way to uncap the 30fps limit.

Verdict

Turn off assists. Stick it in cockpit view and go RACE.

90%

I got this game in hopes that it would be something of a Forza for PC. The car selection looked good, the track selection was not terrible but sadly, this is not really a product I can recommend, especially for those looking for a more serious, mature and functional experience.

1.) The intro video's are too loud, To the point where I had to go in the config files of the game to remove them so that they would not blow out my headphones every time I start the game. Minor annoyance but still worth noting.

2.) Very unstable. This game will crash when loading tracks, it will crash in the middle of races and there is very little that one can do about it. I had to actually reinstall the game entirely (verifying steam install did not help) to make a certain track even load without crashing.

3.) Really poor controls for the gamepad. This one took me by surprise, I would have thought that a game like Need for speed would be extremely controller friendly but sadly that is not the case. The cars feel floaty and unresponsive. There also seems to be some input lag that I can't really explain, it's a common issue that many complain about and for good reason (especially after enjoying the fantastic controls in F1 2013 and GTR2).

4.) Unskippable intro videos to different race types during career. This is where the maturity falls through. When you select new race types, you are greeted with one of two (or three) edgy" racing guys telling you how extreme they are and how much they love speed (and whatever else) while they describe the basics of the race type. I would not make a big deal of this but it is unskippable and their "personalities" are grating and immature at best. It's almost embarassing to watch.

5.) Rather silly race structure. Like other NFS games
date: you can't do a qualifying lap
recommended: you just start the race in whatever grid position that the game randomly puts you in. This is frustrating because you are usually faster than the AI (more about the AI next) and not having any means to compete for a grid position takes away control that you should really have.\n\n6.) The AI is pretty awful. When you play a game like F1 2013 (or any other very realistic racing game)

reviewText:
The second and probably last Shift game to come by Slightly Mad Studios.

It is very similar to Shift but also very different.Graphics/Performance

The graphics on Shift where great for a 2009 game and the same follows for Shift 2. They are similar but slightly better compared to Shift especially on the vinyle quallity. The surroundings on the track are not the greatest but it is hard to notice when you are gunning it down the track at 180 MPH. The car detail is very nice and the paints look very pretty. For me at least the game runs fine but every once in a while when starting a race it gets ♥♥♥♥ing slow for a few moments and goes back to normal. Other than that it performs great on my PC. I'd give it a 9/10 on graphics/performance for a game from 2011.

Gameplay

Well for one the gameplay is totally different from Shift. They took the realisim up a notch on the way cars feel and handle compared to Shift. Drifting has also been made way different compared to Shift and is actually quite hard for most people. Overall the game is probably 2 times as hard as Shift was. The customizing like in Shift sucks just the same with no paintable wheels and hardly any vinyles to apply thus making it impossible to make your own liveries. This makes me feel forced to use the pre made liveries that look bad IMHO which leads me to just paint my cars metallic blue and be done with it. The vinyling system was definatly improved since Shift but they removed a great number of vinyles and made 90% of them only one colour. The AI can be annoying at times especially on small, tight tracks as they will push you out of their way in a hairpin making it almost impossible to win. I'd give gameplay a 8/10 only because of the crappy vinyling system.

Overall

Overall this game is fun and challenging making it very entertaining for me. Nothing beats blasting around the Nordschleife in a 1986 Toyota Corolla AE86 with over 800 HP. If you like racing simulators, buy it. If you like cars, buy it. If you like drifitng, buy it. If you want your Vette to handle like a Lotus and be fast, I'd run and never look back.

reviewText:
Shift 2 Unleashed was a solid racing game and the first one I've played to completion on career mode of 100%.  While I would recommend this game, I do so with some caveats, which I will list in the cons.  The most important point people need to know is that controls have to be customized heavily, I used an Xbox 360 controller for windows and the stock settings were awful, however I followed some guides online and tweaked a couple ini files and was good to go.  Here is the guide that was helpful for me setting up controls: http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2270539

Pros:
- Lots of races
- Good variety of cars
- Most cars look great and have great interiors
- AI makes mistakes on occasion, even knocking themselves out of the race
- AI will bump into you more if you start driving dirty
- Difficulty Levels and driving assists really let you tailor this into either a sim racer or arcade, I like it closer to sim but not all the way there and played with no damage, driving assist line, medium AI, elite handling mode and all driving assists turned off.

reviewText:
Sometimes Shift 2 Unleashed tries a little too hard regarding realism. Due to that I never took place in a real race seat it's just a small and maybe unimportant feeling that I have about it.

I played a lot of NFS Games, some of them were quite funny and challenging, some as Carbon, Most Wanted 2012 and Nitro were more like a stop-doing-that-thing kinda game. Shift 2 Unleashed is absolutly a YES in the NFS series - IF you like to have a challenge. Keep in mind that it is a simulator-near game, with options to make it easier for you.

The career mode is well designed and - for me - well balanced. The amount of cars is great, the money and experience system is also great. You will face a whole load of upgrades and tuning possibilities depending on the installed upgrades. There is even a function to tune your car for a specific track - which is damn great.

In case you enjoy good and less-arcade racing games, Shift 2 Unleashed is a DO.

reviewText:
One of the best racing games for the pc in my opinion. Just bought it yesterday for 5 dollars and have to say its well worth the money. I've always been a forza guy but when it comes to the pc this is about the closest your going to find. But like all games there's pros and cons about it I would like to mention below:

Pros:
-Stunning graphics and great settings for tuning them to fit your pc
-Great selection of cars with many upgrade features
-Fun selection of tracks that you can play day/dusk/night
-Nice multiplayer feature, but hardly anyone on anymore :/
-Driver settings for beginner drivers to help get used corners and braking

Cons:
-Can be pretty difficult to play with the keyboard. I would definitly reccomend a controller but a steering wheel/pedal setup if you really wanna get the full experience.
-Pretty boring in game soundtrack, and dosen't seem to play when racing? Have to use a background media player if you don't like hearing an engine for 20 minutes straight.
-Some might not enjoy having to create an EA account to access multiplayer and other features. Not required to but kinda pushes it on you while you play.
-No rain or other weather. Would have been nice in my opinion.
-The painting feature for vehicles don't offer many options on styles. Same goes for decals.

So is it worth it? YES. And in case your wondering if it will run on your computer don't worry I'm currently maxing everything out with a resolution of 1920x1080 using a GTX650ti getting about 40 to 50 FPS, maybe 35 when there's more scenery.

Don't waste money on a 30 to 60 dollar racing style game. Put 5 to 20 down on this game.
You will be happy and have extra money to get goat simulator.

reviewText:
I gave this game so many tries, and everytime I'd get annoyed at the stupid AI. After seeing how all the recent releases for racing games all seem to be major dissappointments, and NFS: Prostreet being pretty much unfixable, I came back to this game. I decided to stick with the game. In my previous review I gave it a thumbs down because the AI can get incredibly annoying..you'll be slowing down on a corner and the AI hits you and sometimes makes you spin out. I know Im not going slow because a lot of times I'll be up on my opponents bumper. But after a while, you learn how to avoid AI and keeping your space. Then it gets to be a pretty fun game. There are some pros and cons, some of them kinda conflict with each other.

Pros:
-There are different divisions of ranking for cars. This prevents you from farming races over and over until you have a super fast car compared to the competition, and you wipe the floor with them. Ranking works depending on what the car is initially, and then any performance mods you make. This includes things like tires, brake pads, clutch upgrades, turbochargers, engine swap, etc. Forcing you to put more thought into your car build rather than simply buying the most expensive stuff available.
-Engine swaps. No, you cant put a LS1 engine in a Miata. What you CAN do is something like
Take a Toyota Corolla AE86, swap in the V6 Supra engine. Swap in a 20b 3 rotor engine into an RX-7, RX-8, or even a Miata. So they have to generally be from the same company. Not all cars have engine swaps available. I was able to put the NSX V6 engine into an S2000. Since Acura is Honda.
-Manual transmission option. Something devs dont seem to get that many people want nowadays.
-Pretty nice car variety.
-Gorgeous graphics, for its time.

Cons:
-Annoying narrator. Too upbeat. Thankfully you can mute him in audio options. Set dialogue to 0.
-The different divisions and ranking does have a negative to me, and that means you cant do things like take your classic car like my 20b Mazda RX-7 up against modern cars. Or my Skyline powered Fairlady 240z.
-Physics at time feel a bit dated. But it is an old game. Doesnt mean I dont enjoy it.
-As I said in the intro, AI does sometimes ram you off the track. I could be nearly done with the race, finish line right there, taking this tight hairpin turn, and some AI goes too fast around it and sends me flying off course. Then 3 cars get ahead, and Im no longer in the top 3.
-Customization is really limited. Yes, no one is going to see your car but you and maybe a few people, but the possibilities with customization took such a leap backwards. NFS: Prostreet let you choose between so many vinyls, and rims. I could spend such a long time just customizing cars in Prostreet, but theres not much at all to do in Shift 2, its almost pointless.

reviewText:
I bought this as a Gran Turismo style racer for my PC.  It's about half as good as GT.  It's certainly not a bad game, however, I have two main issues.  The first is performance issues: this game struggles to run at decent frame rates, and busy parts of tracks have noticable dips in frame rate.  The second is AI:  the opponents have a tendency to spin you out by nudging your rear end sideways.  It happens in almost every race, so you need to get away from the pack as soon as you can, otherwise you will most likely spin out of control.

These two issues have stopped me from playing so much more of this game, hence only 14+ hours played in over a year.

I would suggest doing research on other equivalent racing games before making this purchase.  Although I do recommend it when on a strong sale discount.

reviewText:
Shift 2 Unleashed is a game designed to sell the player on the concept that they are taming a WILD EXPLOSIVE BEAST IN A HERD OF BEASTS YOU BETTER WATCH OUT-

Its not a simulator. Yes, it does have many sim-esque elements and handling but the cars ocillate faster than my vibrator, every road is made of oil, there are no qualification laps, the AI has been surgically removed from Burnout, and the full body awareness is wasted because EVERYTHING TURNS BLURRY AT THE HIGH SPEED OF 20KMPH. If you want to enjoy this as a racing sim, forget it. If you really do want to play this game, then be prepared to download a handling/material mod and some stuff to remove the blur (which will leave the game lowering the detail of the dash anyway because it assumes its still being blurred). Also be prepared to play disconnected to the internet, period. The only way to prevent the game from crashing at all is to disconnect your computer from the internet, because the beautiful piece of work that is autolog decided to drop a deuce into the game every time it references lap times. Its never getting patched. Its so badly done that BLOCKING THE APPROPRIATE PORTS DOES NOT WORK.

You still want to play? Well, the game is quite fun, if only for that out of control experience. Since you have the option of ruining your suspension and strapping a giant turbo on something that can't handle it, you can go the full ricer experience.

Please don't buy this.

Now it's not as if the normal races where better. You feel like your car behave like nothing you've ever driven: the steering lack of precision and is the most floaty"steering I've ever seen in a racing game
date: not like the overall behaviour of the car was salvaging anything as every car seems to understeer as if you were driving a 18 tons truck
